question: Insect-resistant cotton plants have been genetically engineered by inserting a gene from a/an?
explanation: Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) crops are plants genetically engineered (modified) to contain the endospore (or crystal) toxins of the bacterium, Bt to be resistant to certain insect pests. Currently, the most common Bt crops are corn and cotton. The genetic modification (GM) involves adding a bacterium called Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) to cotton. Modified crop varieties with a Bt trait produce a protein that is toxic to some insect larva.
